metadata.title: Fabrication of a New Electrochemical Sensor for Simultaneous Determination of Codeine and Diclofenac Using Synergic Effect of Feather-Type La3+-ZnO Nano-Flower

sections.text:
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 166 (6) B489-B497 (2019) B489 0013-4651/2019/166(6)/B489/9/$38.00 © The Electrochemical Society
Fabrication of a New Electrochemical Sensor for Simultaneous Determination of Codeine and Diclofenac Using Synergic Effect of Feather-Type La3+-ZnO Nano-Flower Nasrin Arefi Nia,1 Mohammad Mehdi Foroughi, 1,z Shohreh Jahani,2 Mehdi Shahidi Zandi,1 and Nahid Rastakhiz1
1Department of Chemistry, Kerman Branch, Islamic Azad University, Kerman, Iran 2NanoBioeletrochemistry Research Center, Bam University of Medical Sciences, Bam, Iran
The present study was designed to synthesize lanthanum doped feathers-type ZnO nano-flower (feathers-type La3+-ZnO nano-flower), that are specified via Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). To simultaneously determine codeine and diclofenac using feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flower modified carbon paste electrode (La3+-ZnO/CPE), an original cost-efficient and simple methodology is presented. Evidently, La3+-ZnO/CPE proved to be a prospective, stable, sensitive and chemically reliable electrochemical sensor to determine diclofenac and codeine simultaneously with no intervention or overlapping of voltammetric peaks or signals. Codeine electroanalytical sensing was examined via La3+-ZnO/CPE across an extensive concentration range at a relatively low detection limit of 0.01μM, (3S/N). La3+-ZnO/CPE of nanoscale feathers-type La3+-ZnO structure displays favorable practicality in analytical terms to accurately and simultaneously determine diclofenac and codeine within real specimens with exceptional recoveries. The outcomes prove exceptional La3+-ZnO/CPE performance in regard to facile, reliability and sensing capabilities which may favorably decrease the relevant processing expenses for routine analysis and scalable production. © 2019 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/2.1051906jes]
Manuscript submitted January 11, 2019; revised manuscript received March 3, 2019. Published April 12, 2019.
The analysis of drugs for biological fluids is a prominent subject concerning analytical chemistry. Typically, determining different substances within commercial pharmaceutical pills or biological matrices at the shortest possible time and with optimal accuracy is demanded.1,2 Therefore, researchers aim to fabricate a facile, sensitive, expeditious, and stable approach to determine biomolecules and drugs.3–5
Codeine (3-methyl morphine; COD) which is an opiates alkaloid, exists naturally within the poppy plant.6 It is considered a recreational drug with vital impact concerning the nervous system which includes mood-changing and analgesic effects. This drug is commonly used due to its influential opioid analgesic, antidiarrheal, antitussive characteristics and appeases pain in patients, namely the ones subjected to surgery.7,8 Codeine is considered a prodrug, which is inactive itself, but it demethylates toward active morphine via the CYP2D6 liver enzyme. It is initially absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract prior to distribution via intravascular spaces to various body tissues, preferentially up taken within the liver, kidney and spleen. According to the reports of the World Health Organization (WHO), codeine is the most prevalent opiate used throughout the world,9,10
Diclofenac sodium (sodium [o-(2,6-dichloroanilino) phenyl] acetate, DS), categorized as a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), exhibits analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory behavior.11 It is used extensively to treat numerous painful and inflammatory diseases such as migraines, dysmenorrhea, acute gout, renal colic, soft tissue disorders, osteoarthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis.12,13 Additionally, diclofenac can entail severe problems such as strokes and heart attacks, particularly with long term consumption. Moreover, it causes detrimental effects on human health such as renal function disorders, agranulocytosis, gastrointestinal disorders and aplastic anemia,14,15
Various studies presented in the literature reviewed techniques to simultaneously determine diclofenac and codeine. These include capillary electrophoresis via electromagnetic induction detector16 and ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy via reversed matrix depiction of the Beer–Lambert law (CPA-matrix method).17
Numerous electroanalytical approaches are reviewed to determine diclofenac18–20 and codeine21–23 at single mode, however, based on our research, reports on simultaneously determining the aforementioned composites via electrochemical approaches are scarce.24
zE-mail: foroughi@iauk.ac.ir
Even though electrochemical approaches entailed favorable results, relatively high potentials should be implemented to directly oxidize these analytes, thus entailing potential interference risks. Such issue may be appeased via modifications.25–31
In the nanotechnology and nanoscience fields, a semiconductor metal oxide nanosubstance with novel morphological structure is considered an active area of studies concerning potential devices.32–35 Fabrication of diverse morphologies concerning semiconducting material presented in the shape of tetrapods, nanorods, nanocrystals, nanowires, nanoflowers and nanoparticles with original synthesis methods are introduced as prominent research areas.36 From the different II-VI semiconductor materials, ZnO is considered a prospective multi-purpose oxide material with a direct bandgap (∼3.3–3.6 eV) and high exciton binding energy (∼60 meV) appropriate for catalytic uses. ZnO nanostructures’ optical, structural and catalytic characteristics enables them to be optimal systems in developing radically novel devices concerning the areas of defect emission, photcatalyst, field emission, solar cells and sensors.37,38 Nanostructures of differing morphology and relevant growth mechanisms are favorable for many uses. Interesting morphologies are an option since insignificant modifications in reaction factors involved amidst the synthesis approach such as using catalyst and impurity doping may cause surface relaxation and reconstruction. There have been global attempts to enhance the device efficiency via impurity doping in ZnO wurzite crystal structures.39–41 It is established that ZnO nanostructures that are transition metal doped are examined to determine various growth morphologies, sensing uses and optical characteristics. Doping plays a prominent role in the synthesis of exceptional nanostructures, namely vertical or aligned nanorods, tetrapods, nanoflowers and nanowires for particular uses. Lanthanum is also a dopant which possesses numerous advantages as an alternative to other elements. Lanthanum ionic radius is greater compared to Zn, thus influencing numerous structural characteristics whilst being simple to utilize within ZnO crystal architectures. La is mainly used for doping within ZnO nanostructures to acquire nanostructures’ varied morphology and contains improved catalytic characteristics.42,43
Accordingly, the present study aimed to design, fabricate and describe the preparation and suitability of a feather-type La3+-ZnO nanoflowers modified carbon paste electrode (La3+-ZnO/CPE) as a novel electrode to detect the codeine in aqueous buffer solutions, and subsequently to assess the analytical performance of the modified electrode in quantification of codeine in the presence of diclofenac. The real samples were eventually examined to detect codeine and diclofenac using new proposed electrochemical sensor.
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 130.70.8.131Downloaded on 2019-04-16 to IP

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text:
Reagents and solutions.—Zinc acetate (C4H6O4Zn.2H2O), lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3.6H2O) and sodium citrate were procured from Merck and implemented as received. Codeine and diclofenac was bought from Sigma-Aldrich and implemented as received. By dissolving a suitable amount of codeine and diclofenac in water and diluting the mixture to 100 mL with distilled water using a 100 mL volumetric flask, a codeine and diclofenac solution of 0.01 M was prepared. The resulting solution was stored in a refrigerator in a dark environment. Additional dilute solutions were created using serial dilution phosphate buffer solutions. By mixing a stock solution of 0.1 mol/L NaH2PO4 and 0.1 mol/L Na2HPO4, a phosphate buffer solution (PBS) 0.1 mol/L was created. HCl or NaOH was used to modify the pH. The remaining materials were analytical reagent grade. All solutions were created using double distilled deionized water. Additional purification was not implemented for the chemicals used.
Apparatus.—KBr discks on a JASCO FT/IR-460 PLUS instrument was used to record FT-IR spectra. A Philips analytical PC-APD X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Cu and Kα radiation (α1, λ1 = 1.54056 Å, α2, λ2 = 1.54439 Å) was used for X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) in order to clarify the products’ arrangement. KYKY, EM 3200 scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to analyze nano-flowers’ surface morphology. The EDX, energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry is a prominent nondestructive tool used for analysis such as chemical composition analysis. SAMA 500 Electro analyzer that was controlled using a personal computer at SAMA Research Center, Iran was used for electrochemical determination. A Pt wire auxiliary electrode, a saturated calomel reference electrode (SCE) and a carbon paste working electrode (CPE, modified or unmodified) formed the three electrochemical cell system.
La3+-doped feather type ZnO nano-flowers preparation.— Feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers were assembled via a single step hydrothermal approach that is facile, green and productive. Normally, 0.549 g of C4H6O4Zn·2H2O (2.5 mmol), 0.0046 mol of lanthanum nitrate and 0.735 g of sodium citrate (2.5 mmol) were dissolved into 40 mL deionized water whilst being stirred to acquire a clear aqueous solution. Subsequently, 4 mL of NaOH with 4.0 M concentration was added to the solution whilst being meticulously stirred. The concoction was placed into 50 ml or Teflon line stainless steel autoclave and subjected to heat of 120 °C temperature for a period of 8 hours. Upon cooling down to room temperature, white precipitations were distinguished and separated from this solution using centrifugation and washed using absolute ethanol and distilled water numerous times prior to being dried at a temperature of 60 °C for a period of 2 hours under air atmosphere.
Modified electrode preparation.—Initially, 0.1 g of feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers was mixed by hand with 0.9 g of graphite powder in a mortar and pestle. The mixture was added by about 0.7 mL of paraffin oil and mixed for 20 min to appear a uniformly-wetted paste that was then transferred into the end of a glass tube. A copper wire was placed into the carbon paste to hold the electrical contact. In addition, a new surface was created by inserting additional paste out of the tube and polishing with a weighing paper.
The same way was also applied to prepare unmodified CPE in the absence of feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers for comparison the products.
Real samples preparation.—A refrigerator was used to keep urine samples upon collection. A 20 minute centrifuging process at 2000 rpm was implemented on 10 mL of the sample. A 0.45 mm filter was used to filter the supernatant. A phosphate buffer solution of pH 7.0 was used to dilute the filtered result 5 times. The resulting solution was then transported into the volumetric cell for analysis with no need for additional pretreatment. To determine the codeine and diclofenac sample content, the standard addition method was implemented.
Codeine (acetaminophen-codeine) and diclofenac commercial pharmaceutics tablet were bought from a drugstore in Kerman, Iran (Sobhan Company). Each of the tablets had a dose of 15 and 50 mg codeine and diclofenac respectively, as significant components that were electrochemically active without other typically prevalent additive drugs as guaranteed by the manufacturer in the accompanying informational leaflet. 15 and 50 mg of acetaminophen-codeine and diclofenac tablets was diluted to 10 mL with 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0) respectively. Then various diluted solution volumes were put into a 25 mL volumetric flask and diluted to the mark with PBS pH 7.0. The proposed method was used to analyze the codeine and diclofenac contents by utilizing the standard addition method.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Nanostructures characterization.—The product morphology was evaluated via SEM. Figures 1a, 1b) depicts the ZnO image where tens of ZnO nanowires produce a feather-type cluster.
Figure 1C displays the FT-IR spectra of feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers sample in the 400–4000 cm−1 frequency range. The feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers FT-IR spectrum exhibited profound vibrational bands at low frequency regions of approximately 576 and 465 cm−1, accredited to metal–O vibration. The absorption at ∼3421 cm−1 is considered as a result of –OH groups’ symmetric vibration concerning the absorbed H2O molecules. The ∼1631 cm−1 peak pertains to O–H groups, also relevant to the adsorbed H2O molecules.44
The main La3+-ZnO nano-flowers’ characteristic diffraction peaks are in accordance with ZnO (JCPDS card No. 36–1451) standard patterns with hexagonal wurtzite phase, implying La doping will not alter the pristine ZnO backbone, as depicted in Figure 1D. With the increase of La within the ZnO, the properties peak at 2θ = 36.08° weakens and shifts to small angle reflections when La is increased in ZnO. The addition of La ions with f electronic and greater atomic radiuses within the ZnO grain boundary results in ZnO atoms order degree, thus entailing the grain’s limited development, refinement and crystallinity reduction.45
The breadth of diffraction peaks implies the product’s nano-sized nature and the average crystallite size (t) was derived via Debye– Scherer formula as 47.0 nm. t = 0.9 λ/β cos (θ) such that λ is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation (1.54056 Å for Cu lamp), θ is the diffraction angle and β is the full width at half-maximum (FWHM).46
To evaluate the material purity, the detection of elemental composition existing within feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers was conducted using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), as depicted in Figure 2. From feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers EDX spectrum, the existence of zinc, lanthanum and oxygen is evident with no impurities. feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers EDX mapping images are presented in Figure 2 that show zinc, lanthanum and oxygen are composites of the synthesized product.
Electrochemical properties of modified electrodes.—To perform the electrochemical characterization of the La3+-ZnO/CPE in the presence of 10.0 mM [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− redox couple (1:1, molar ratio) containing 0.1 M KCl, the cyclic voltammetry (CV) technique was applied. The results obtained on La3+-ZnO/CPE were compared to that on the bare CPE.
The CV measurements were performed in [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− solution at the different scan rates in the range of 10–800 mVs−1 on La3+ZnO/CPE (Fig. 3A) in order to determine the electrochemical active surface areas (A). Due to the above, Randles–Sevcik equation for a reversible electrode process was employed.47 The peak current (Ip) is defined by the equation (Eq. 1):
Ip = ± (2.69 × 105)n3/2AD1/2Cv1/2 [1] where: A – the electrode surface area (cm2), n – the number of electrons involved in the redox reaction (n = 1 for K3[Fe(CN)6]), D – diffusion coefficient (D = 7.2 × 10−6 cm2 s−1), C – the concentration of K3[Fe(CN)6] (C = 10.0 mM). Then, the electroactive area for La3+-ZnO/CPE can be determined from the slope of the plot of Ipa
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 130.70.8.131Downloaded on 2019-04-16 to IP
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 130.70.8.131Downloaded on 2019-04-16 to IP
vs. v1/2, and the electrochemical active surface area of La3+-ZnO/CPE was evaluated as 0.012 cm2. For comparison, the electroactive surface area of bare CPE was also calculated as 0.03 cm2.
EIS is considered an influential probe in determining the adjusted electrode’s electron transfer traits. Figure 3B shows the bare CPE and La3+-ZnO/CPE Nyquist plots within 1.0 mM [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− possessing 0.1 M KCl. The electrode surface electron transfer resistance i.e. Rct is equal to EIS semicircle diameter which may be useful in describing the electrode’s interface characteristics. A large semicircle of about 855 (Rct) diameter was evident at the bare CPE (curve a) which shows a significantly low electron transfer rate among the CPE and electrochemical probe [Fe(CN)6]3−/4−. Upon the addition of the feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers to the CPE electrode, there was a reduction of the Rct down to 249 . Figure shows the impedance variances at the adjusted electrodes which validates the exceptional conductivity of the feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers which expedites electron transfer. The evident impedance variances stemmed from the feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers synergistic impact in [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− electrochemical response as well as the surface area traits.
The EIS was also used to calculate the standard heterogeneous rate constant (k0) for each modification of the electrode according to equation (Equation 2):47
k0 = RT F2RctAC
[2]
where k0 is the standard heterogeneous electron transfer rate constant (cm s−1), R the universal gas constant (8.314 J K−1mol−1), T the thermodynamic temperature (298.15 K), F the Faraday constant
(96485 C mol−1), Rct is the electron transfer resistance ( ), A the electrode surface area (cm2) and C the concentration of the [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− solution (1.0 mM). The obtained k0 values for the bare CPE and La3+ZnO/CPE were 1.0 × 10−2 and 3.6 × 10−2 cm s−1, respectively. Considering that, the k0 values are a measure of the kinetic facility of the redox pair, in which a system with high k0 value will achieve equilib-
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 130.70.8.131Downloaded on 2019-04-16 to IP
rium in a shorter time than a system with low k0 value, which in this case will achieve equilibrium in a longer time. Thus, with the La3+ZnO/CPE sensor, the k0 value is greater than with La3+-ZnO/CPE > CPE, indicating in this case, a faster transfer of electrons in comparison with the other electrode.
Electrochemical behavior of codeine at the surface of various electrodes.—This paper investigates the electrochemical conduct of codeine at the unmodified CPE and modified CPEs. CV obtained at potential sweep rate 50 mV s−1 for a 50.0 μM codeine in PBS (pH 7.0), at the unmodified CPE (Fig. 4A, curve b), ZnO/CPE (Fig. 4A, curve c) and La3+-ZnO/CPE (Fig. 4A, curve d). It is evident that, the oxidation of codeine at ZnO/CPE and La3+-ZnO/CPE surfaces was conducted at the potential 1040 mV vs. SCE, which is around 110 mV more negative than that observed in the case of the unmodified CPE. A comparison of oxidation peak currents for codeine at the unmodified CPE, ZnO/CPE and La3+-ZnO/CPE indicate an enhancement of nearly 2.09 and 3.4 μA in the anodic peak current at the ZnO/CPE and La3+ZnO/CPE, which is due to the increase in the surfaces area of ZnO/CPE and La3+-ZnO/CPE as compared with unmodified CPE. In addition, doping large atom like La on ZnO may create Lewis acid regions on the metal oxide sites, which may be have a significant effect on electron transfer on the electrodes. Thus, increases in sensor sensitivity stemmed from ZnO and La3+-ZnO nanoparticles which was to be expected.
Effect of pH.—The influence of pH on the electrochemical behavior of codeine was studied in the pH range of 2.0 to 9.0 using PBS solutions. There were no detectable peaks for tramadol in the 2.0 and 3.0 pH. It was found that the peak potential is shifted toward less positive values with increasing the pH of the solutions which indicates the involvement of the proton in the electrochemical reaction. As can
Scheme 1. Probable oxidation mechanism for codeine and diclofenac.
be seen in Fig. 5B, there is a linear relationship between the peak potential (Ep) and pH with a regression equation:
Ep (V) = −0.0499pH + 1.3486 ( R2 = 0.9964)
The slope of the equation is close to the Nernstian value of −59 mV which indicates that the equal number of protons and electrons are involved in the oxidation of codeine. This result is consistent with the codeine oxidation mechanism which is shown in Scheme 1.48 As is evident in Fig. 5A, the oxidation peak current of codeine, increases up to pH 7.0 and then decreases. Therefore, pH 7.0 was selected as an optimum pH value for the electrochemical experiments. In
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 130.70.8.131Downloaded on 2019-04-16 to IP
addition electro-oxidation mechanism of diclofenac molecules can be described as follows (Scheme 1).12
Potential sweep rates effect.—The influence of scan rate on the oxidation peak current of codeine was investigated on the La3+-ZnO/CPE by cyclic voltammetry. According to Fig. 6A, peak current intensity is directly proportional to scan rate i.e. increases in scan rate entail increases in peak current intensity. Moreover, current is directly proportional to scan rate square root at the range 10–100 mVs−1 as presented in Fig. 6B which is a strong indication that codeine redox reaction is controlled by diffusion. According to these results, oxidation peak potential had a positive shift when scan rate was increased. Furthermore, in the course of reaction among La3+-ZnO/CPE and codeine, there are kinetic limitations at higher scan rates.
Data from rising sections i.e. Tafel regions of current-voltage curves acquired at 10 mVs−1 were used to plot analytes Tafel curves. This is shown in Fig. 6C. The electrode reactions’ electron transfer kinetics effect the Tafel regions of current potential curves. Results show that a 0.1144 V Tafel slope, indicating one electron rate determining step (RDS) for the electron process for charge transfer coefficient (α) of 0.48 as shown in Fig. 6D.47
Chronoamperometric measurements.—Codeine La3+-ZnO/CPE chronoamperometric measurements was conducted by modifying the working electrode potential at 1100 mV vs. Ag/AgCl/KCl (3.0 M) for different codeine concentrations as depicted in Fig. 7A at PBS (pH 7.0), respectively. Regarding electro-active materials, in this case codeine, with D as the diffusion coefficient, thus electrochemical reaction current at mass transport limited status is presented by the Cottrell equation:47
I = nFAD1/2Cbπ−1/2t−1/2 Here, D and Cb are the diffusion coefficient in terms of (cm2 s−1) and the bulk concentration in terms of (mol cm−3), respectively. I vs. t−1/2 test plots were used to determine the most suitable fits for various codeine concentrations (Fig. 7B). The resultant straight line slopes were then plotted versus codeine concentrations (Fig. 7C). The Cottrell equation and resultant slope were used to derive D mean values, which was 1.0 × 10−6 cm2/s for codeine, respectively.
Codeine voltammetric determination.—A codeine calibration curve was acquired via differential pulse voltammetric (DPV)
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 130.70.8.131Downloaded on 2019-04-16 to IP
measurements within optimum experimental conditions. Usual DPVs for various codeine concentrations are presented in Fig. 8A. Codeine slope value of 0.0701 μA/μM resulted in a linear range of 0.1 to 900.0 μM (Fig. 8B). The detection codeine limit was 0.01 μM.
Determination of codeine and diclofenac simultaneously.— As previously mentioned, codeine and diclofenac, exist together in numerous pharmaceutical structures. Thus, the next attempt was to determine codeine and diclofenac simultaneously. Hence, the suggested DPV approach was conducted for determining codeine and diclofenac simultaneously in synthetic samples by utilizing La3+-ZnO/CPE. In this regard, by concurrently increasing concentrations, both analytes were determined, as shown in Fig. 9.
The relative standard deviations were 2.1% and 2.5% for 5 consecutive determinations of codeine and diclofenac respectively. Therefore, it was clarified that when implementing the suggested DPV approach, codeine and diclofenac simultaneous determination has the same efficacy as when individually determined. Results also indicated that the
recommended electrode can be effectively utilized for simultaneously determining codeine and diclofenac.
Sample analysis.—In order to demonstrate the pragmatic application of the proposed method codeine and diclofenac were determined in acetaminophen-codeine tablet, diclofenac tablet and urine samples, at La3+-ZnO/CPE. Every sample was treated according to section codeine and diclofenac voltammetric determination. Five parallel determinations were carried for each sample. Table I presents the results. The recoveries were 97.5%–102.3% and the RSD was lower than 3.3%. The obtained results prove the applicability of the proposed method in real samples.
Stability and repeatability.—La3+-ZnO/CPE long term stability was evaluated across a three week time period. On this basis, when the adjusted electrode was not utilized for three weeks and preserved within an atmosphere for three weeks, the tests were repeated. Based on cyclic voltammograms, there were no changes in codeine oxidation
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 130.70.8.131Downloaded on 2019-04-16 to IP
peak potential apart from a 2.7% decrease in comparison with the primary reaction (Fig. 10).
The adjusted electrode’s antifouling characteristics in regard to codeine oxidation was examined via CVs. Voltammograms were documented with the existence of codeine upon potential cycling of 15 times at 100 mV s−1 scan rate. The outcomes showed no changes in peak potentials and a decrease of 3.21% in currents. Based on the results, applying the adjusted La3+-ZnO/CPE increases the sensitivity whilst decreasing codeine fouling effects (Fig. 11).

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: A facile and one-pot feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flower hydrothermal synthesis was fabricated and implemented to simultaneously determine codeine and diclofenac as an electrochemical sensor, which was unprecedented. The feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flowers are essentially adjusted carbon paste electrode that mutually facilitate the transfer of electrons as well as mass transport and electrocatalytic activities. The feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flower significantly reduced overvoltage and enhanced electrochemical reaction of codeine and diclofenac in regard to sensitivity. Moreover, La3+-ZnO/CPE was used to directly determine codeine and diclofenac within real specimens with no treatments and favorable results, showing that La3+-ZnO/CPE is an auspicious electrode for on-site identification of codeine and diclofenac recreational drugs.

metadata.abstractText: The present study was designed to synthesize lanthanum doped feathers-type ZnO nano-flower (feathers-type La3+-ZnO nano-flower), that are specified via Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). To simultaneously determine codeine and diclofenac using feather-type La3+-ZnO nano-flower modified carbon paste electrode (La3+-ZnO/CPE), an original cost-efficient and simple methodology is presented. Evidently, La3+-ZnO/CPE proved to be a prospective, stable, sensitive and chemically reliable electrochemical sensor to determine diclofenac and codeine simultaneously with no intervention or overlapping of voltammetric peaks or signals. Codeine electroanalytical sensing was examined via La3+-ZnO/CPE across an extensive concentration range at a relatively low detection limit of 0.01μM, (3S/N). La3+-ZnO/CPE of nanoscale feathers-type La3+-ZnO structure displays favorable practicality in analytical terms to accurately and simultaneously determine diclofenac and codeine within real specimens with exceptional recoveries. The outcomes prove exceptional La3+-ZnO/CPE performance in regard to facile, reliability and sensing capabilities which may favorably decrease the relevant processing expenses for routine analysis and scalable production. © 2019 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/2.1051906jes]
